caption: In December 2020, a video supposedly showing a living triceratops in Indonesia being taken down from a truck a bed was widely circulated online

candidates.title: Was a Living Triceratops Found in Indonesia?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows a real triceratops being unloaded from a truck in Indonesia.
Rating:
Miscaptioned
About this rating
In December 2020, a video supposedly showing a living triceratops in Indonesia being taken down from a truck a bed was widely circulated online:
This video, which has racked up hundreds of thousands of views, garnered a mixture of comments. Some joked about this being a real video of a living triceratops, some pondered if it was possible, while others simply wondered what the heck was going on.
For starters, this is not a living and breathing triceratops. The rhinoceros-looking dinosaur lived during the Cretaceous period — about 68 million years ago — but went extinct along with all other non-avian dinosaurs during the Cretaceous–Paleogene (K–Pg) extinction event about 66 million years ago. In other words, it would be unusual to see a living, breathing triceratops in the wild today.
This video actually features a triceratops puppet at a dinosaur theme park in Indonesia called Mojosemi Forest Park. While we're not exactly certain how this puppet was created, a longer video from this dino-themed amusement park appears to show that this triceratops is operated possibly by two people inside of an elaborate costume:
https://fb.watch/2oxNZxaLhE/
While some may have taken pause when they first saw the triceratops video, other videos from Mojosemi Forest Park clearly show that dinosaurs have not actually been brought back from extinction.
https://fb.watch/2oyqfR9Klr/

result.explanation: This assessment is evidence-based. The news caption accurately reflects the event described in the external evidence from Snopes.  The caption states that in December 2020, a video of a supposed living triceratops in Indonesia being unloaded from a truck circulated online.  Snopes confirms this, further clarifying that the video actually depicts a triceratops puppet at a dinosaur theme park.  The date and the general description of the video's online circulation are consistent. Therefore, the caption is accurate and used in the correct context.
supporting_evidence: Source 1: Snopes article confirms the circulation of the video in December 2020 and clarifies that it shows a triceratops puppet, not a real dinosaur.
Source 1: Snopes article title: "Was a Living Triceratops Found in Indonesia?"
Source 1: Snopes article content: "In December 2020, a video supposedly showing a living triceratops in Indonesia being taken down from a truck a bed was widely circulated online"

final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation confirm the accuracy of the news caption. The caption accurately describes a video that circulated online in December 2020, showing what appeared to be a living triceratops being unloaded from a truck in Indonesia.  External evidence from Snopes confirms this, clarifying that the video actually depicted a triceratops puppet at a dinosaur theme park. There are no discrepancies between the internal and external checks, leading to high confidence in the caption's accuracy and appropriate contextual usage. The location information extracted from the news content, although somewhat abbreviated, is consistent with the external source which specifies Mojosemi Forest Park in Indonesia. The external source also strongly supports the date and the content of the video as described in the original caption.  There is complete agreement between the internal and external validation, leading to a very high confidence score.  The high confidence score stems from the strong evidence supporting the original caption and the complete lack of conflict between internal and external validation mechanisms.  There is no reason to believe that the caption is out of context based on the available evidence.   Therefore the conclusion is that the caption is in context, and completely and accurately reflects the event, which is further supported by readily available external verification.  Therefore the OOC flag is False and the confidence score is 10 out of 10.  This represents the highest level of confidence achievable given the information provided.
